body:
@mbehrendt alternatively, we could choose the first one and return a warning (and, of course, document the behavior). If we expect majority of Java actions to have, say, up to 50 classes (including dependencies) - making the entry point parameter optional could be convenient. 

By the way, one potentially nice heuristic could be to sort classes by date before applying 'javap' on each -- this would likely minimize the chance of not finding the entrypoint, because dependencies would typically be older than the 'main' project classes.

> eg by making --main mandatory.

Then it's a required (positional) argument and not optional as implied by dash dash. The point of making it optional is for the cli to try and infer it - but as suggested in several comments above the cli doesn't have to try too hard and give up quickly if the cli can't figure it out and ask the user for help. This makes it possible to have a suggested common idiom which makes the need to specify additional parameters unnecessary.
@csantanapr ,yes, I will try to submit a pr according to latest comments.
@rabbah @bjustin-ibm , please help review, thank you.

@rabbah what is the suggested exact behavior of this automated detection mechanism, such that we deliver an great user experience. eg i think the timeout shouldn't be longer than 5 seconds. how is the cli going to react if more than one matching classes is found within these 5 seconds?

also, we should be open to treating -main as mandatory parameter, if there is too much that has to be considered / can go wrong with the cli 'magic'
@mdeuser Has this PR been superseded by #1007? If so, please close this one.

One more option for a heuristic search: check the `Main-Class` property in the manifest, and if exists - check whether the same class contains also Whisk's `main` method signature. 

Having 'regular' `main` method in the class is convenient for local execution and testing, so I would assume that it might be a reasonably common practice to have both in the same class.

PG 103 - for test case changes (comments).   PG "passed" (only issue was due to timing related failure regarding activation record accounting in an alarm feed test - not related to the affected tests).
Yes, PR #1007 obviates the need for this PR.  Closing

@rabbah - Ready for merge.  If there are other follow up test case related comments/issues, I'd like to handle those via a separate issue as this fix is blocking this CLI PR from being ready.   Thanks!

User error, I should have read the docs.
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/docs/catalog.md#translating-text
@csantanapr - Would you please merge.. let me know if I need to rebase.  Thanks!
As an (unsatisfactory) workaround, you can make the REST call yourself; run `wsk -v` to get the payload once, then post it again changing the name of the action and of the main class.
If I understand correctly, we should be able to reproduce by building one jar with two classfiles, where `main` from class 1 attempts to dynamically load class 2?
yes, using the context class loader - e.g., `Thread.currentThread().getContextClassLoader().loadClass("second.class.name")`. Other class loaders might work -- I am not entirely sure.
sounds like docker-engine problems in travis VM

Here is one example:
https://travis-ci.org/openwhisk/openwhisk/builds/150994577
it will be useful to see the version of docker travis is using, we should stick to 1.9.1

The docker version is printed in the log: `Docker version 1.9.1, build a34a1d5`.

We do stick to 1.9.1, docker is setup in `tools/travis/setup.sh`
We sent email to Travis support to report the problem.
To stay tune you can create a github trigger in OpenWhisk ðŸ˜¸
Ready when squashed as far as I'm concerned :+1:
@psuter squashed and ready!
the updates are in. PG1 107 came up clean.  travis now clean

@mdeuser please review changes.
PG 108
PG 109

Closing as duplicate of #575 to address `wsk feed` in CLI

For `wsk action get --help` new go-CLI takes cares of this

```
 $ ./bin/go-cli/wsk action get --help
get action
Usage:
  wsk action get <name string> [flags]

Flags:
  -s, --summary   summarize entity details

Global Flags:
      --apihost string      whisk API host
      --apiversion string   whisk API version
  -u, --auth string         authorization key
  -d, --debug               debug level output
  -i, --insecure            bypass certificate checking
  -v, --verbose             verbose output
```

Closing since how to build under Vagrant is documented in [tools/vagrant/README.md](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tools/vagrant/README.md)
TLDR;

```
#build like this
cd openwhisk
./gradlew distDocker
```
How about adding the tldr to the top level readme (and include deploy "fresh" as well)?

@rabbah what do you mean? to doc `wskdev fresh` in main README?

I'm brainstorming on how to best organize README.md, CONTRIBUTING.md and maybe create a new DEVELOPER.md

Want to keep README short and focus to an user that wants to run openwhisk locally but not interested on contributing or modifying the code. the fastest and easier way to get OW running locally and try it out.

Was looking at angular2 repo as a pattern, what you think?
[README.md](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/README.md)
[CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
[DEVELOPER.md](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/DEVELOPER.md)
[COMMITTER.md](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/COMMITTER.md)

@rabbah is right, these should go to `group_vars/all` to be overridable per environment.

I didn't mean to move the entire suite tests/src/system/basic/WskBasicTests.scala â†’ ...c/whisk/core/cli/test/WskBasicTests.scala but only the test you needed to be in the core package. Looking at the tests more carefully, it may make more sense to leave the test in the system package but make Subject less protected. Some of these tests should run as part of system suite.

These packages will eventually be in openwhisk-catalog, so will the relevant docs move there?
If we remove the cloudant bits which show off how to use packages, we will need to replace them with new samples.
Do we have a feed example without alarm or cloudant? I'll audit the rest. Keep in mind when the other samples also move then more bits have to come out or be replaced.
@rabbah nevermind, I know what you mean know, `packages.md` uses cloudant ðŸ˜µ

Closing this PR, alarm and cloudant is spread everywhere. I will spent a lot of time re-writing the docs, I preferred to spend the time making open source package for alarm and couchdb/cloudant available and explaining with source code what a feed is.

I think modifying the `assert` is probably better (I normalized the ones in CLIActionTests as follows:

```
assertTrue("Expected '" + exp + "' which is missing in log for activation " + activationId, present);
```

so that you always have the activation ID. I think this is likely sufficient to do for CLIRulesTests instead of the verbose flag.
Related to our discussion in https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/800#issuecomment-238732271 @csantanapr.

@rabbah The tests did get an activation id but they actually check the log for a string with `logsForActivationContain` which made the assertion fail. The first assertion which got the activation id passed. So in this case only getting the activation id would not have helped.

I don't think this is still valid:

```
> wsk action invoke /whisk.system/samples/echo --blocking
ok: invoked /whisk.system/samples/echo with id 646457dbaadd49a5b9b4ddbaa39223a9
{
    "activationId": "646457dbaadd49a5b9b4ddbaa39223a9",
    "annotations": [],
    "end": 1470901383752,
    "logs": [],
    "name": "echo",
    "namespace": "guest",
    "publish": false,
    "response": {
        "result": {},
        "status": "success",
        "success": true
    },
    "start": 1470901383745,
    "subject": "guest",
    "version": "0.0.1"
}

> bin/go-cli/wsk action invoke /whisk.system/samples/echo --blocking -i
ok: invoked /whisk.system/samples/echo with id 851664d8294946b38155d74b18e01cc8
{
    "namespace": "guest",
    "name": "echo",
    "version": "0.0.1",
    "subject": "guest",
    "activationId": "851664d8294946b38155d74b18e01cc8",
    "start": 1470901393743,
    "end": 1470901393748,
    "response": {
        "status": "success",
        "success": true
    }
}
```
From the jenkins job output, you can't tell what the activation id - can you; maybe I missed it?
Sterlizing got me through. Will leave open and coopt for @paulcastro's upgrades.

@csantanapr Including the "archive" in the image helps only with having the data hopefully closer, but you still have to load it in the memory of the action. not sure how long that takes, but I would think it takes some non-negligible  time

Checking into "no such module 'Foundation' " when using latest Swift 2.2.1 release.  Tried earlier Swift 2.2 release and get same error.  

It appears Foundation is not included in versions of Swift 2.X after the 1-11a snapshot.  Experts tell me Foundation is tracking 3.X not 2.X.

2. multi line log message
